q:
Your friend got a burn on his calf, you have no burn
gel in your kit, what should you do?
a: Cover it and keep it wet.
c: Leave the burn area open, the air will\n dry it out.
d: Leave the burn area open if transport is\n less than 1 hour.

q:
You meet a 42 year old female in the aftermath of a
suicide bomber, she has trouble breathing and you can
see that her chest only moves on one side. Her SpO2 is
85%. What should you do?
a: Apply the nasopharyngeal airway.
b: Place her lying on her damaged side\n down.

q:
A police officer has been shot in the face during a
shootout. He is awake and sitting up, spitting out some
blood every few minutes. What is the best way to render
care?
a: Get your airway kit ready and start\n sedation.
b: Place him on his back on a stretcher and\n insert a nasopharyngeal airway.
c: Make sure he is properly immobilized.
d: Allow him to maintain his own airway and\n keep his position as care is rendered.

q:
A 16 year old boy runs from a subway bombing, he
suddenly starts seizing. When you get to him his
seizures stopped and his breathing returns to normal.
The scene is secure, what is your next step?
a: Put him in the passenger seat in the car\n next to you.
b: Start to carry him to the command post.
d: Place him in the recovery position.

q:
You are in a safe house, your partner is wounded and
you have done your MARCH algorithm when you notice that
she is shivering. What should you do?
a: Use your ready heat blanket..
b: Check her eye movements and do a full\n eye exam.

q:
A 31 year old male has been impaled and stuck in a
vehicle after flipping it over, he had an arterial
bleed from his left thigh that you stopped with a
tourniquet. He is in severe pain when you start to
extract him, what is a reasonable option for pain
management?
a: Ketamine, 100 mg.

q: What should you keep in mind when giving IV fluids?
a: If I don't have full blood, giving\n fluids are not necessary.
b: I should always give at least 1L of\n fluids to all casualties with weak\n pulse.
c: I should only give it to maintain a\n systolic BP of 80 to 90 mm Hg..
d: It should be administered to all\n casualties with traumatic injuries.

q:
You find yourself in a mexican standoff. What should
you do?
a: Wait for help from your brothers.
b: Stand completely still, the human eye\n can detect movement.
c: Move off the X to cover.

q:
You are in a safe house when you receive a victim with
a tq on his leg. He has a strong radial pulse at a
normal rate, hes breathing is slow and he is
unresponsive. The medic tells you during MIST that he
gave him repeated doses of iv morphine. What could you
give the victim?
a: Naloxone.

q:
The first officer on a breacher team stumbles on his
way through a door and hits his head and knocks himself
unconscious. When the raid is over his colleagues drags
him to you. He is still unresponsive, he has irregular
breathing, high blood pressure and a slow pulse. How
should you maintain his capnography?
a: 36–40 mm Hg.

q:
What is a contraindication of the nasopharyngeal
airway?
a: Facial trauma with possible fractured\n base of the skull.

q:
Your presented with a victim from a gunfight, he has a
chest seal covering a bullet hole on his chest. He
begins to complain about shortness of breath, he is
worried and his pulse is racing. What should you do?
a: Use duct tape to cover the chest seal.
c: Place a 14-gauge × 3.25-inch needle in\n the chest at the 3rd ICS at the sternal\n border.

q:
A security guard was struck with a baseball-bat to his
abdomen. He has some pain and bruising but tells you he
is fine. He wants to get back out there and begins to
walk around the room. He says he is thirsty and reaches
for his water bottle. Should he be allowed to drink?
a: Yes its perfectly fine to drink fluids\n and self-hydrate.
b: No, he needs an IV and a fluid bolus.
c: Yes, but only clear, warm fluids
d: No, he needs to be prepped for OR, no\n fluids per os allowed.

q:
A 45 year old female got trapped in a burning vehicle,
when you arrive she is extracted and you see that her
clothes are still smoldering. It looks like her whole
left leg has a deep burn injury, she is writhing in
pain. What should you do first?
a: Wrap burn injuries in wet sterile\n dressings.

q:
During a raid to free hostages an officer gets shot
while fast roping. He falls and fractures his left
ankle, his right thigh has a bullet wound that is
spurting blood. What should you do?
a: Call for casevac.
b: Get him to apply his tourniquet to the\n left thigh.
c: Rush to his aid and bring your medkit.

q:
You are in an active shooter event and your colleague
get caught in a crossfire and sustains a bullet wound
to his arm. You shout to him to get to cover behind a
nearby car and apply self-help. Which phase of care are
you?
a: Tactical field care.

q: How can morphine cause a lower blood pressure?
a: It sends signals to the brain to make\n the blood go slower.
c: It causes your arteries to dilate.
d: It stimulates your baroreceptors in the\n aortic branch.

q: What size should your needle be for decompression?
a: 14-gauge, 3.25 inch (8.3 cm).

q:
A 28 year old ambulance driver is breathing heavily,
having a gunshot wound to her right chest. The
perpetrator is somewhere nearby, you assess that you
are in the warm zone. What is your next step?
a: Start the nearest car to get her\n offsite.
b: Perform needle decompression,\n midclavicular, between the 2nd and 3rd\n intercostal space.
c: Extract to a casualty collection point.
d: You put on gloves and put your hand on\n the wound, then replace your hand with a\n chest seal.

q:
A man has been stabbed several times in his thorax. His
blood pressure is slightly elevated, his pulse around
110 and he is breathing quickly with SpO2 at 93%. What
should you do?
a: Get an IV going and start walking blood\n bank procedure.
b: Apply high-flow oxygen with a\n nonrebreathing mask.
c: Cover all the holes with chest seals.
d: Talk him through tactical breathing to\n slow his breathing rate.

q:
A 17 year old female is dug out of the rubble right
after a building collapsed. She is confused and has
blood coming out of her ears. What kind of injury do
you suspect?
a: Traumatic brain injury.

q:
The police have applied tourniquets to a victim that
has been shot in both his legs. Now the victim mumbles
and when you check his pulse it is weak. What is you
next step?
a: Put in recovery position.

q:
You are standing at the casualty collection point, a 25
year old female has a gunshot to her left leg, TQ has
been applied in the hot zone. She is awake and now
shivering and acting anxious. What should you do?
a: Give her something hot to drink.
b: Remove wet clothing, and apply a thermal\n barrier.
c: Hug her to make her warm.
d: Get an IV going with fresh blood.

q:
A middle ages man was at the site of a suicide bombing.
He is moaning and slipping into unconsciousness. He
seems to have only small shrapnel wounds and a
laceration on his head. What is the best systolic blood
pressure for this patient?

You arrive at the scene where an IED has gone off. You
assess the scene as warm zone. You encounter a victim
lying on his back, snoring and severe facial trauma.
What should you do first?
a: Get him to recovery position.

q:
A blastvictim has been waiting for evacuation for about
an hour. Just as you place him on the stretcher you
notice that the right upper arm is swollen, the arm is
cool, radial pulse is weak and the capillary refill is
about 5 seconds. What should you suspect?
a: Closed humeral fracture.

q: When is th TQ your weapon of choice?
a: A patient with a gunshot wound bleeding\n heavily from his neck.
b: A victim with a through and through\n wound on his calf, bleeding lightly.
c: A 5 year old child with a gunshot wound\n through his right hand that is minimally\n bleeding.
d: A patient with a gunshot wound to her\n left thigh, clothes soaked in blood.

q:
You stop the bleed on a 40 year old females upper
thigh. You assess that she lost about 1L of blood. Now
she says she feels cold, she looks pale and clammy.
What type of shock is she experiencing?
a: Emotional.

q:
You get to a victim in the indirect threat zone, he is
bleeding from his groin area. What should you do?
a: Use 2 TQ´s as he is bleeding heavily.
c: Pack the wound with a hemostatic\n dressing.
d: Give him 1 gram of TXA via IV infusion.

q:
You receive a victim at the casualty collection point,
she had a sucking chest wound and have been treated
with a chest seal. Now she experience increased
difficulty in breathing. What should you do?
a: Talk her through tactical breathing.
b: Immediately get ready to do airway\n interventions.
d: Remove and throw away the chest seal.

q:
You decide to do a needle decompression on an obese
victim, where is the correct site?
a: Just below the first rib, outside the\n nipple.
c: Fifth intercostal space, anterior\n axillary line.
d: It doesn't matter, as long as its on the\n side of the patient and the needle goes\n in.

q:
A 32 year old female was involved in a terror event
where fire was used as a weapon. Both her legs have
full-thickness burns. Her BP is 87/65, P 122, RR 20.
You are in the cold zone. What should you do?
a: Obtain IV/IO access and begin fluid\n resuscitation.
d: Get an ambulance to drive her to the\n closest burn unit.

q: Why should you avoid wound packing in the hot zone?
a: The package takes up too much space.
b: Time constraints make the procedure\n unsafe.
c: Assuring a patent airway is a greater\n priority than hemorrhage control in the\n hot zone.
d: TQs are just better for bleeding.

q:
An operator used a flash-grenade that caused a fire
inside the building they were raiding. Now the last man
out is having trouble breathing, he is wheezing and has
soot in his face. What do you suspect?
a: Internal bleeding in the lungs.

q:
You have put a TQ on your partners upper leg to stop a
bleed. 15min later he complains of severe pain, his BP
120/70, P 105, RR 24. What would be a proper treatment?
a: Administer buddy-aid.
b: Reassess tourniquet effectiveness and\n administer 50 mg of ketamine IM.

q:
A work friend of yours get shrapnel into his eye, what
should you do before evacuating him?
a: Wrap bandages around his head that\n protects both eyes.
b: Do a rapid field vision test.
c: Cover the eye with a rigid eye shield.
d: Put your safety goggles on him.

q:
You are presented with a burnvictim, all extremities
have suffered burn injuries. When should you start
giving fluid resuscitation?
a: After you loaded the patient in an\n ambulance but prior to arriving at\n hospital.
b: As soon as you get an IV/IO in.
c: After you have given pain medication.

q:
You only have one TQ, which patient would you give it
to?
a:
18 year old male with a penetrating
 wound to the upper right chest and left
 thigh, shot by a sniper, lying where he
 fell, not moving.
b:
32 year old male with a gunshot wound to
 the right arm, shot by sniper, ducked in
 cover, bright red blood spurting from
 the wound.
c: 18 year old female with an bullet wound\n to lower arm, shot by sniper, in cover,\n she is applying pressure herself.
d: 46 year old male with bullet wound in\n neck, shot by sniper, bright red blood\n spurting from the wound.

q:
A 30 year old female police officer has sustained a
self-inflicted gunshot wound to her leg, she applied a
TQ. Now she is in pain, has clammy skin and weak pulse.
How can you help her manage the pain?
a: Oral transmucosal fentanyl lozenge at\n 800 mcg.

q:
A victim sustain a penetrating injury to the chest.
What is the most common sign of tension pneumothorax?
a: Lowered SpO2.

q:
Your friend got shrapnel in her eye, when should it be
removed?
a: In the warm zone.

q:
You have multiple casualties on your casualty
collection point. When retriaging you find a patient
with a chestseal covering a gunshot wound having
difficulty breathing, he is begging you for help. What
should you do?
a: Speak calm words of comfort.

q:
Your crew is taking care of business when you stumble
upon a gunshot victim with severe facial injuries. You
lay him on a stretcher but he tries to sit up, what
should you do?
a: Make sure the straps on the stretcher is\n tight before transport.
b: Administer Ketamine IV to sedate him and\n manage pain.
c: Allow him to sit up -it may help open\n his airway.
d: Put him in recovery position, even if he\n protests.

q:
The nasopharyngeal airway seems like a rather small
tube, what is correct?
a: The inside of the tube is big enough for\n air for normal breathing.
b: It can be used as a definitive airway.
c: It allows you to inspect the lower\n airway using a flashlight.
d: It prevents the tongue from sliding back\n and blocking the airway.

q:
A 42 year old EOD-operator burnt his chest, face and
arms when inspecting an IED. When he arrives to you he
has trouble breathing, has a coarse throat and soot in
his face. He is breathing fast and shallow. What should
you do?
a: Get him on monitor asap!.
b: Manually stabilize the spine, something\n might have broke.
d: Make him drink at least 1L water.

q:
There are some things you need to consider before
moving a casualty in the hot zone, what are they?
a: What equipment is the casualty wearing.
b: How many people you need, where is your\n goal of movement, what technique will\n you use.
d: The final hospital that will receive the\n victim.

q: Where should a TQ work?
a: Groin area.
b: Underneath the arm in the armpit.

q:
In the aftermath of an explosion you find a 21 year old
female, she has sustained burns on her torso and arms.
She has no visible bleeds. Her pulse is weak, she is
slipping into unconsciousness  and she only responds to
pain. What should you give her?
a: Fentanyl intranasal.

q:
Which patient will you transport first if only one can
go?
a: Gunshot wound to belly, no radial pulse,\n responsive to painful stimuli.
b: Male with shortness of breath due to\n gunshot wound to chest, chest seal in\n place.
c: Female with arterial bleed of the right\n leg, stopped with TQ.

q:
You suspect your patient has a injured chest, what
symptoms are most likely?
a: Increased breath sound.
d: Crepitus or crackling sounds when\n palpating the chest.

q: Which of the following are good principles?
a: Treat the casualty.

q:
Which of the following is NOT one of the zones related
to 3 phases of care?
a: Hot zone.

q:
Your brother in arms got injured, it's painful but he
can still function in combat. What can you give him to
manage pain and stay in the fight?
a: Ketamine IV.

q: What do people die of the most in a tactical situation?
a: Extremity bleeding.

q: How can you quickly assess chock in the field?
a: Heart rate and redness of the face.
b: Level of consciousness and quality of\n radial pulse.

q:
Why is it dangerous to give excessive fluids IV to a
bleeding patient?
a: It dilutes clotting factors and will\n interfere with clot formation at the\n bleeding site.
c: It will make the patient nauseous.
d: It will create free radicals in the\n blood.

q: When is a oropharyngeal airway a bad idea?
a: When the gag reflex kicks in.
b: When the patient has a head injury.
c: When the victim has lost a tooth.
d: When the victim is a child.

q: What will make a TBI worse?
a: Too low blood pressure .

q:
So you opened up an airway using the chin-lift method,
now you're needed elsewhere. What is a fast and easy
way to keep the airway open?
a: Nasopharyngeal airway.

q:
You stumble upon 3 victims in the warm zone, who should
you help first?
a: Victim A – shot in the head and\n unconscious with agonal breathing.
b: Victim B – gunshot to the stomach, awake\n and in pain.
c: Victim C – blood spurting from a thigh\n wound.

q:
Your work friend has been shot in the chest. You have
put a chest seal on, now his breathing is more and more
labored. What do you do next?
a: Surgical airway.

q:
You are an EMT arriving to evacuate a casualty who
suffered a gunshot wound to her face. Two "helpers" are
trying to put her down on a stretcher but she is
fighting to get up, what is the best course of action?
a: Quickly sedate and intubate her.
b: Allow her to continue to sit up and lean\n forward.
c: Get more people to be able to logroll\n her.
d: Hold her down and give her oxygen.

q: How can you check a patient's airway from afar?
a: Shout a question that requires a\n response from the casualty.
b: Check for a bluish color of the nail\n beds.

q:
You decided to do a needle decompression of a victim
with chest trauma and respiratory distress. You take
the victims hand and place it thumb up in her armpit,
you decide that just below her hand is a good place for
puncture. Describe that site in medical terms.
a: 4th or 5th intercostal space at the\n anterior axillary line.
b: 1st or 2nd intercostal space at the\n anterior axillary line.
c: 2nd or 3rd intercostal space at the\n sternal border.
d: Just lateral of the Angle of Louis.

q:
What is the symtoms associated with severe hemorrhagic
shock?
a: Tachycardia.

q: When is a rapid infusion of IV fluids acceptable?
a: To a victim bleeding into the abdomen.
b: To a victim with uncontrolled junctional\n bleeding wound.
c: To a dehydrated victim with no other\n injuries.
d: To a victum with traumatic Brain Injury.

q:
You are at the casualty collection point, who should be
evacuated first?
a: A casualty of a land mine who has lost\n the foot with bleeding controlled by a\n tourniquet.
b: A casualty who was shot in the head with\n no vital signs.
c: A casualty who was shot in the abdomen\n and now has an absent radial pulse.

q: What should you check after splinting a fracture?
a: Check to ensure that the extremity pulse\n is not absent.
b: Wrap the extremity in ready heat blanket\n to reduce hypothermia.
c: Make sure all bones are in the same\n direction.

q: When may IV opioids be used to reduce pain
a: Operator with minor injuries, he can\n continue to fight.
c: Victim with a chest wound and\n respiratory distress.

q: When using a tactical casualty care approach:
a: I will have the best outcome for the\n most victims.
b: Those who die will die, I can't fight\n fate.
c: Every gunshot victim gets a TQ.
d: Open airways is the highest priority.

q:
Your team gets caught in a fire during a mission. Your
teammate inhaled the hot smoke, he now has trouble
breathing, falling into unconsciousness with a blocked
airway. What intervention should you do?
a: Put him in recovery position.
d: More oxygen through the nasopharyngeal\n airway.

q:
You get shot in a gunfight, your left thigh oozing of
fresh blood. You put a TQ on yourself. You are 45min
from the nearest hospital. What is your best tactics.
a: Replace the tourniquet with a improvised\n hemostatic gauze.
b: Loosen the tourniquet, time will heal\n every wound.
c: Put a pressure dressing over the\n tourniquet, and remove the tourniquet\n yourself.
d: Embrace the suck and leave the\n tourniquet in place.

q: In the tactical care setting what is true:
a: Victims who are thirsty should never be\n allowed to drink.
b: The Intraosseus path should be\n considered if an IV can't be placed.
c: Pulse oximetry and other electronic\n monitoring are sources of misdiagnosis\n and should never be trusted.

q:
In what zone is it appropriate to start giving fluids
to treat shock?
a: Hot zone.

q: What is not a part of the lethal triad?
a: Hemorrhage.

q:
Why is a fentanyl lozenges sometimes better than
morphine?
a: No need to start an IV to administer.

q:
Where is the correct puncture site for needle
decompression?
a: Second intercostal space, mid-clavicular\n line.
b: Second intercostal space, above the rib.
c: Fourth intercostal space, below the rib.

q:
There was a firefight, you are ducking in cover with a
severe extremity bleeding. How should you stop the
bleed?
a: Put your fingers in the wound and clamp\n the artery.
b: Use of external hand pressure to\n compress artery.

q: How should you use a hemostatic gauze?
a: Directly to bleeding site.
b: Penetrating wounds to the stomach with\n minimal outwards bleeding.
c: Open head wounds with minor bleeding and\n brain matter exposed.

q:
You have packed a wound in the axilla using hemostatic
gauze, after moving the patient from the warm zone to
the cold zone you notice that the dressing is soaked
with blood. What is your next step?
a: Nothing, the bleeding will probably\n stop.
b: Put more pressure on the wound.
c: Remove the soaked hemostatic gauze and\n replace with a fresh one.
d: Clamp the artery with your fingers.

q: What are 2 symtoms of shock?
a: Severe pain and minimal injury.
d: Decreased level of consciousness and\n weak radial pulse.

q: What ways can you administer morphine?
a: Intramuscular.

q:
What of the options is a sound tactical medical
principle?
a: Stop tactical movement to arrange\n ambulances for evacuation.
b: All trauma casualties needs a helivac.
c: Prevent additional injuries and minimize\n public harm.

q:
A friend of yours gets shot in the chest, you have put
on a chest seal. 30min later she has trouble breathing.
What should you do?
a: Put her in recovery position.
d: Make sure she has a high O2-flow.

q:
You are ventilating a patient that has a chest seal.
You use a bag valve mask. What should you consider?
a: Use big movements, the patient needs\n air.
c: The arise of a tension pneumothorax.

q:
What is a good choice of antibiotics in the tactical
setting?
a: Cefazolin.

q: How would you apply a tourniquet in the hot zone?
a: Straight to the wound.
b: As a "just in case" measure to be\n tightened if needed.
c: About 5 fingers over the wound directly\n to exposed skin.

q:
What should you do before you give narcotics to a
wounded police officer?
a: Secure the airway with a nasopharyngeal\n airway.
d: Make sure the police officer is strapped\n to a gurney.

q: What are the benefits of Ketamine?
a: It has no negative effect on blood\n pressure.
c: It will always put the patient to sleep.
d: The victim, if armed, can still be in\n the fight.

q: What will make a TBI worse?
a: Hypovolemic shock.

q: What statement about the tourniquet is true?
a: Damage to an extremity is uncommon if\n the tourniquet is left on for less than\n two hours.
b: Tourniquets are often left in place for\n several hours during surgical\n procedures.
d: All active personnel should have a\n tourniquet at a standard location on\n their gear.

q: What is true regarding TXA?
a: All of the options.
b: It prevents the breakdown of forming\n clots.
c: For best effect it should be given\n within one hour of injury.
d: It shouldn't be given if time of injury\n is greater than 3h.

q:
You are giving TXA, your patient experience a blood
pressure drop. What should you do?
a: Nothing, this is normal.
b: Add 1L Lactated Ringers to adjust the\n blood pressure.

q: What is a good measure of good fluid resuscitation?
a: SpO2 of 96% or greater.
d: Strong radial pulse and improved level\n of consciousness in the absence of a\n traumatic brain injury.

q:
Your taking care of a kid, what can you do under Airway
that might help?
a: Lift the kids legs.
c: Get something underneath the kids\n shoulders to slightly lift them.

q: What is TXA´s primary function?
a: Prevents clots that are forming from\n breaking down by the body.
c: Prevents production in hypothalamus of\n clot breaking cells.
d: Helps unloading CO2 from red blood\n cells.

q:
You have a victim with a bleeding from the base of the
neck. What is this hemorrhage called?
a: Massive hemorrhage.

q:
What should you use to decompress a tension
pneumothorax?
a: Whatever is available.

q:
What is it called when air is trapped on the wrong side
of the lung?
a: Traumatic fibromyalgia.

q:
Why is it important to aggressively treat a femoral
bleed?
a: Its always good to be aggressive.
b: A femoral bleed will kill you instantly.
c: Its not, the femoral bleed will sort\n itself out.
d: You can bleed to death in as little as 3\n minutes.

q:
A young fireman has been shot through his right thigh.
A TQ was used and now in the cold zone he is awake,
breathing fast, has a weak radial pulse and seems
worried. What should you do?
a: Get him into a sleeping bag and crawl\n down there yourself.
b: Remove wet clothing and apply dry\n clothing and blankets.
c: Get a doctor to give him warm fluids.
d: Give fresh blood through a Ready-Heat\n blanket.

q:
A policeman is struck in his helmet with a baseball
bat, he is unconscious but breathing normally. What
should you do?
a: Place the policeman in recovery\n position.
b: Crack open a ready heat blanket and put\n over his body.
c: Get an IO in and flush it.
d: Conduct a full body cavity search.

q:
A 34 year old female caught a bullet in a crossfire. It
went through her scapula. She is now distressed, crying
that she can't breathe. You can a see a bullet wound on
her back that's bubbling. What should you do?
a: Apply trauma dressing.
b: Get ready to open the airway.
c: Wipe the wound and put a chest seal on\n it.

q:
You are going into a cold zone near an explosion site,
you find a young man lying on his back who has facial
trauma and strange breathing, he seems unconscious.
What should you do first?
a: Perform a jaw thrust.
c: Sit him up, check for pulse.

q: What is a positive aspect of the nasopharyngeal airway?
a: It is a great way to stop a nosebleed.
b: It is more easy to extract.
c: It is better tolerated by a conscious\n patient.

q:
You are just about to deploy with your team into a
hostile area when one of your team mates starts
seizing, he stops after about 2 minutes but is still
unresponsive, breathing rate is 22. What should you do?
a: Remove his weapon and coms, put him in\n recovery position.
b: Logroll him to check for spinal injury.
d: Sit the patient up against a tree.

q:
During a firefight operation one of the firefighters
falls from the second floor onto a railing, he sustains
an open fracture on his thigh, blood is oozing out, and
a closed fracture on his right wrist. What should you
do now?
a: Do not touch the victims until spinal\n immobilization is done.
b: Apply a tourniquet to the thigh.
c: Set the fractured leg right -then apply\n TQ.

q:
During an ongoing act of terrorism a 35 year old
firefighter has been shot in the chest, he is in pain
and complains of shortness of breath. You get him to
cover in a nearby building. What should you do next?
a: Put him in recovery position.
d: Get that hole covered with a chest seal.

q:
Your taking care of a victim where fire has been used
as a weapon. The victim has soot in her face and
wheezing sounds when breathing. She is strapped to a
gurney but wants to sit up, what should you do?
a: Tell her to stay down for her own good.
b: Try to sedate her and manage pain.
c: Establish cervical spine immobilization\n procedures regardless.
d: Allow her to be in whatever position she\n wants.

q:
A 35 year old man is bleeding from a junctional wound.
What should you do?
a: Sit him up and place the bleeding high.
b: Pack the wound with a hemostatic\n dressing.
c: Give 1 gram of TXA via IV infusion.
d: Put pressure with your knee on pressure\n point.

q:
Applying direct pressure to a wound is the right thing
to do when?
a: Alert victim with trickling bleeding in\n the hot zone.
b: Unresponsive victim with minimal\n bleeding in the warm zone.
c: Conscious victim with heavy bleeding in\n the warm zone.
d: Conscious victim with heavy bleeding\n during direct threat care.

q:
At the casualty collection point you have a 33 year old
female with a gunshot wound to her upper right back
that was earlier treated with a chest seal. Now she is
anxious and says that it's hard to breathe. What should
you do?
a: Manually burp the chest seal.

q:
A young woman is lying face down on the ground after an
explosion, she is awake, talking but seems confused.
There are several other victims nearby. What should you
do?
a: Place the patient in the recovery\n position.
b: Sit the patient up, and move to the next\n patient.

q:
You have treated your colleagues sucking chest wound
with a nonvented chest seal. She is now experiencing
increased difficulty breathing. What should you do?
a: Immediately intubate.

q:
A 16 year old schoolgirl is at the base of some long
steps during a mass shooting. She is confused and
bleeding from her ears. What should you suspect?
a: Possible head injury.

q:
You have run through your MARCH on a patient with a
broken ankle. You are prepping for evacuation when your
patient tells you she's cold. What should you do?
a: Cover with a blanket.
